facts.statement: Poland’s Creotech Instruments signed a contract with the European Space Agency to build and launch a satellite constellation.
facts.evidence: Poland’s Creotech Instruments has signed a €52 million (223 million zloty) contract with the European Space Agency (ESA) to build and launch a constellation of Earth observation satellites.
facts.explanation: The text clearly states that Creotech Instruments signed a contract with ESA to build and launch a satellite constellation.

facts.statement: The contract signed between Creotech Instruments and ESA is the biggest ever contract in history between Poland and ESA.
facts.evidence: ‘This is the biggest contract in history signed between the ESA and a Polish entity,’ said finance minister Andrzej Domański.
facts.explanation: The statement claims the contract is the biggest ever between Poland and ESA, which is supported by the text. Therefore, the statement is True, but the question mentions 'in history' broadly. The statement is correct based on the text, so I will correct the previous label.

facts.statement: The satellite constellation will include at least three satellites with different optical capabilities.
facts.evidence: Creotech, which is the largest Polish space firm listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange, says that the constellation will contain at least three satellites – one radar, one high-resolution optical and one lower-resolution optical.
facts.explanation: The text specifically mentions three satellites with different optical capabilities, confirming the statement.

facts.statement: The project aims to support nuclear energy development in Poland.
facts.evidence: The project will provide data to support 'effective crisis management, the safety of residents and infrastructure, and protection of the natural environment' in Poland.
facts.explanation: The text discusses environmental protection and crisis management but does not mention nuclear energy development.

facts.statement: Out of the €52 million, over €30 million will be spent on subcontractors, including Polish companies.
facts.evidence: Out of the €52 million for the project – which is titled Country Awareness Mission in Land Analysis (CAMILA) – €25.6 million will go to Creotech itself with the rest spent on work executed by subcontractors.
facts.explanation: Only €25.6 million will go to Creotech; the remainder will be spent on subcontractors, totaling approximately €26.4 million—less than €30 million.

facts.statement: Creotech conducted a successful space mission called EagleEye in 2024, which reached orbit.
facts.evidence: According to the company, 'a significant part' of the system has already been tested in space during a trial EagleEye mission conducted in 2024 by Creotech. It was then that the largest and most technologically advanced Polish satellite to date successfully reached orbit.
facts.explanation: The text states that the EagleEye mission was conducted in 2024, and the satellite reached orbit, supporting the statement.

facts.statement: Polish astronaut Sławosz Uznański-Wiśniewski will be the first Pole to travel to space.
facts.evidence: Later this year, Poland is set to launch its first mission to the International Space Station (ISS), headed by Polish astronaut Sławosz Uznański-Wiśniewski, who will become the second Pole in history to travel to space and the first to stay aboard the ISS.
facts.explanation: The text specifies that he will be the second Pole in history to travel to space, so he will not be the first.

facts.statement: Signal uses end-to-end encryption (E2EE) to secure messages.

facts.statement: Signal stores user profile pictures and group membership records.

facts.statement: High-ranking US security officials regularly communicate on Signal for national security matters.
facts.evidence: Data expert Caro Robson, who has worked with the US administration, said it was "very, very unusual" for high ranking security officials to communicate on a messaging platform like Signal.
facts.explanation: The text indicates it is unusual but does not specify whether they do or do not, so the information is not given.

facts.statement: Disappearing messages on Signal can violate laws related to record-keeping.
facts.evidence: The Atlantic's Jeffrey Goldberg said some of the messages in the Signal group he was added to disappeared after a week. This may violate laws around record-keeping - unless those using the app forwarded on their messages to an official government account.
facts.explanation: The text states that disappearing messages may violate record-keeping laws unless forwarded to a government account, implying an actual threat of violation.

facts.statement: Signal threatened to withdraw from the UK app store if backdoors were mandated by law.
facts.evidence: Signal threatened to pull the app from the UK in 2023 if it was undermined by lawmakers.
facts.explanation: The text explicitly states Signal threatened to pull the app if security was compromised by law.

facts.statement: The US government uses secure custom-built encrypted systems, known as Scifs, for national security discussions.
facts.evidence: The US government has historically used a sensitive compartmented information facility (Scif - pronounced "skiff") to discuss matters of national security. 'The whole system is massively encrypted and secured using the government's own highest standards of cryptography,' she said.
facts.explanation: Detailed explanation confirms that Scifs are the secure locations used, employing high encryption standards.

facts.statement: Sharing confidential data with the wrong person can compromise security regardless of encryption levels.
facts.evidence: No app can prevent someone peeking over your shoulder if you are using your phone in a public space. Or as one critic more bluntly put it: 'Encryption can't protect you from stupid.'

tenses.sentence: AI technology aimed to improve efficiency on egg farms has been awarded £2.6m in government funding.
tenses.explanation: This clause uses the past simple tense 'aimed' which indicates a completed action or intention in the past.

tenses.sentence: AI technology aimed to improve efficiency on egg farms has been awarded £2.6m in government funding.
tenses.explanation: The present perfect 'has been awarded' indicates a completed action with relevance to the present, emphasizing the recent occurrence of the award.

tenses.sentence: The AI analyses a range of data gathered from sensors on a farm, including listening to the sound the hens make, to identify any potential problems.
tenses.explanation: The present simple 'analyzes' indicates a general truth or a habitual action relating to the AI's function.

tenses.sentence: The Facilitating Learning Opportunities, Cultivating Knowledge and Welfare through Integrated Sensing and Expertise (Flockwise) system has been developed by Oxford-based FAI Farms, alongside Cumbria's The Lakes Free Range Egg Company and Newcastle University.
tenses.explanation: The present perfect passive 'has been developed' emphasizes that the development occurred at an unspecified time before now, with relevance to the present.

tenses.sentence: The Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra) hopes the three-year trial will improve animal welfare and eventually reduce egg prices for British shoppers.
tenses.explanation: The present simple 'hopes' shows a current belief or expectation about the future outcome.

tenses.sentence: FAI Farms claims the system can identify the sounds birds make when stressed or unwell and alert the farmer.
tenses.explanation: The modal 'can' + base verb 'identify' indicates ability or possibility in the present.

tenses.sentence: Their BirdBox system is already used to check the hens' environment, monitor equipment, record feed data and gather information about the quality of the eggs.
tenses.explanation: The present simple passive 'is used' indicates a habitual or established use.

tenses.sentence: Defra said the technology would help hens "live longer and healthier lives and is good for the environment too, because longer-lived fowl have a smaller carbon footprint".
tenses.explanation: The modal 'would' indicates a conditional or anticipated future event from a past perspective.

tenses.sentence: If rolled out nationwide, Defra hopes the project could "make for up to 1.7 billion more eggs laid a year, and a £280 million increase to UK farmers' income".
tenses.explanation: The present simple 'hopes' indicates a current belief about the possibility.

tenses.sentence: In a statement, Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Steve Reed said: "Government support for cutting-edge technology is making a real-world difference to British farmers and boosting their profits.
tenses.explanation: The past simple 'said' reports a completed action — reporting a statement.

tenses.sentence: Government support for cutting-edge technology is making a real-world difference to British farmers and boosting their profits.
tenses.explanation: The present continuous 'is making' indicates an ongoing action happening at the moment of speaking.

tenses.sentence: Farmers could even pass these productivity gains on to consumers, by charging lower prices for their eggs, ultimately putting more money in people's pockets.
tenses.explanation: The modal 'could' plus base verb 'pass' indicates possibility or potential capability.

tenses.sentence: Science and Technology Secretary Peter Kyle said: "Not only is this work putting British farming at the cutting edge—it's ensuring our morning fry-ups remain proudly homegrown.
tenses.explanation: The past simple 'said' reports a completed action of speech.

tenses.sentence: "Not only is this work putting British farming at the cutting edge—it's ensuring our morning fry-ups remain proudly homegrown.
tenses.explanation: The present continuous 'is putting' indicates ongoing action occurring at the moment.

tenses.sentence: "Not only is this work putting British farming at the cutting edge—it's ensuring our morning fry-ups remain proudly homegrown.
tenses.explanation: The present continuous 'is ensuring' indicates an ongoing process or action.

facts.statement: The AI technology for egg farms received government funding.
facts.evidence: AI technology aimed to improve efficiency on egg farms has been awarded £2.6m in government funding.
facts.explanation: The text clearly states that AI technology has been awarded government funding.

facts.statement: The Flockwise system analyses data including hen sounds to detect problems.
facts.evidence: The AI analyses a range of data gathered from sensors on a farm, including listening to the sound the hens make, to identify any potential problems.
facts.explanation: The text specifies that the system analyses hen sounds as part of its data collection.

facts.statement: The Flockwise system was developed solely by Oxford-based FAI Farms.
facts.evidence: The Facilitating Learning Opportunities, Cultivating Knowledge and Welfare through Integrated Sensing and Expertise (Flockwise) system has been developed by Oxford-based FAI Farms, alongside Cumbria's The Lakes Free Range Egg Company and Newcastle University.
facts.explanation: The text lists multiple collaborators, not just FAI Farms.

facts.statement: Defra hopes that the trial will improve animal welfare and reduce egg prices.
facts.evidence: The Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra) hopes the three-year trial will improve animal welfare and eventually reduce egg prices for British shoppers.
facts.explanation: The text explicitly states Defra's hopes for both improved welfare and lower prices.

facts.statement: FAI Farms claims their system can identify when hens are stressed or unwell.
facts.evidence: FAI Farms claims the system can identify the sounds birds make when stressed or unwell and alert the farmer.
facts.explanation: The text supports FAI Farms' claim about stress and health identification.

facts.statement: The BirdBox system is used only to monitor the hens' environment.
facts.evidence: Their BirdBox system is already used to check the hens' environment, monitor equipment, record feed data and gather information about the quality of the eggs.
facts.explanation: The system has multiple functions, not just environmental monitoring.

facts.statement: Defra believes the technology will help hens live longer and be better for the environment.
facts.evidence: Defra said the technology would help hens 'live longer and healthier lives and is good for the environment too, because longer-lived fowl have a smaller carbon footprint'.
facts.explanation: The statement is directly supported by the text.

facts.statement: If implemented nationwide, the project could produce up to 1.7 billion additional eggs annually.
facts.evidence: If rolled out nationwide, Defra hopes the project could 'make for up to 1.7 billion more eggs laid a year, and a £280 million increase to UK farmers' income'.
facts.explanation: The potential number of additional eggs is explicitly mentioned.

facts.statement: Steve Reed said government support is helping British farmers and increasing their profits.
facts.evidence: In a statement, Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Steve Reed said: 'Government support for cutting-edge technology is making a real-world difference to British farmers and boosting their profits.'
facts.explanation: The quote clearly indicates support aiding profits.

facts.statement: Peter Kyle emphasized the importance of British farming staying at the technological forefront.
facts.evidence: Science and Technology Secretary Peter Kyle said: 'Not only is this work putting British farming at the cutting edge...'
facts.explanation: While the quote highlights technology's role, it does not explicitly state it's about staying at the forefront, so the emphasis is on 'putting British farming at the cutting edge' which could be interpreted as support, but it's not explicitly about 'staying at the forefront' in the text provided.
